title: From Kipchoge to Chelsea via the Tour de France, Ineos and Sir Jim Ratcliffe are just getting started in sport
text:
One of the first moves made by Sir Jim Ratcliffe’s petrochemicals company Ineos when it bought the historic Swiss football club FC Lausanne-Sport was to order a rebrand of the club’s crest. The new image would feature some subtle changes, with the ‘O’ in Sport redrawn to replicate the distinctive ‘O’ in Ineos and a new orange trim pulled from Ineos’s branding.

Naturally Lausanne’s supporters weren’t enamoured with the idea, and their protests eventually forced the redesign to be scrapped. Yet the fact that the plan ever came to fruition seemed at odds with Ratcliffe and his executive put in charge, David Thomas, both of whom professed to be lifelong football fans. They may like or even love sport, but sprucing up the crest of a century-old football club with corporate imagery did not suggest much understanding of the game.

Ineos ran into a number of difficulties at Lausanne, who were soon relegated, and it would have been enough to put most people off. Instead Ratcliffe got a taste for it, and if anything his forays into the world of sport have become even more audacious. His company has pledged £110m to Ben Ainslie’s attempt to bring the America’s Cup back Britain for the first time since 1855, bought cycling’s Team Sky, now Team Ineos, winning the Tour de France in July, and this summer bought the football club down the coast from his Monaco home, Nice.

We’ll tell you what’s true. You can form your own view. From 15p €0.18 $0.18 USD 0.27 a day, more exclusives, analysis and extras.

The grandest of all Ineos’s ambitious plans came this weekend, funding the enormous 1.59 challenge which saw Eliud Kipchoge become the first person ever to complete a marathon in less than two hours. As the world watched, the Kenyan crossed the line in 1.59.41 with Ineos’s name on the his chest, followed by a pack of Ineos-branded pacesetters.

Perhaps we should be grateful that Britain’s richest man is spending his fortune in the world of sport. That is certainly one image of Ratcliffe, the benevolent billionaire, founder of the Go Run for Fun charity and all-round sports enthusiast doing what many of us might if we had his bank balance. As Ratcliffe put it: “We make six or seven billion dollars a year in profit, so what’s wrong with investing a bit of that in sport?”

Yet there are some common threads in his ventures which aren’t so reassuring. Confrontation and controversy seem to come as part of the deal. One of Ratcliffe’s more petty fallouts was with the British Olympic Association (BOA) over the name of his America’s Cup team, which he wanted to call Team GB, which is owned by the BOA. He said he would be promoting Team GB’s name in a “patriotic light”, but after being refused he wrote to the BOA inviting them to “take a long walk off a short plank”, declaring he had changed the name to “Team UK, which I much prefer”.

Ratcliffe’s move to buy Team Sky drew accusations of greenwashing as he plastered his petrochemicals company’s brand over a cycling team – “I don’t really understand what greenwashing is,” he said – and he brazenly launched the new Team Ineos at the Tour de Yorkshire, where the fracking industry he strongly supports is such a divisive topic for local communities. It drew protesters to the start line but then that seems par for the course: Ratcliffe has fallen out with just about everyone from environmentalists to the government, and even his neighbours.

Perhaps we get another sense of his character from his sporting feats. Ratcliffe has ridden long-distance bike races in his 60s, completed expeditions to both the North and South Poles and pushed himself so hard at the New York marathon needed a drip at the finish. This is someone driven to the point of obsessive when it comes to achieving his goals, and it explains why he would not accept failure at the 1.59 challenge. This wasn’t an attempt, it was a statement of fact: a marathon can be run in less than two hours and Ratcliffe was going to prove it, even if his legs weren’t covering the ground. He found the fastest runner on the planet, the springiest shoes on the market (or off it), on the flattest ground on the mildest morning with a raft of world-class pace-setters and a green laser beam lighting the path, and he succeeded.

This, it seems, has been the overriding point so far. Grand gestures, big shows of sporting exhibitionism and history written, from cycling’s pinnacle to one of athletics’ great barriers, all played out under the Ineos flag.

What comes next? Ratcliffe has looked into buying Chelsea Football Club, near his Knightsbridge headquarters, although that appears unlikely any time soon. In the meantime Ineos will fly its flag up the mountains of the Tour de France and over the oceans of the America’s Cup, and you suspect this is just the start. Success in sport can be addictive, and now Ratcliffe has got the taste, we are likely to be seeing an awful lot more of Ineos in the years to come.
